Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Soot Archeology - Fullerenic Nanostructure as an Indicator of C5 Precursor Chemistry

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks to establish a correlation between fuel-air ratio and curvature in soot nanostructure. Partial pre-mixing contributes new pathways to soot formation via partial oxidation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Accordingly the first objective is to demonstrate the relevance of C5-membered rings to fullerenic nanostructure in soot using a simple gas jet diffusion flame fueled with C5 precursor species. The second objective is demonstrating C5 production, via partial premixing using a Bunsen flame configuration. The third objective is to test fullerenic formation across temperatures for comparison to model calculations using a flat flame burner fueled with real and surrogate fuels. Modeling will be used to guide experimental efforts and support the correlations sought between nanostructure and gas phase chemistry. Calculated and measured temperature fields will serve as input to temperature-time profiles.

Results of this study will create a new paradigm ¡V using fullerenic nanostructure as a tracer for partial premixing. By showing a definitive link between nanostructure and specific precursor species this study will provide a foundation for inferring ?¶ within soot forming regions of practical combustors and engines based upon the degree of curvature observed in the soot. Beyond combustion interests, demonstrating a relation between molecular growth species and solid-state structure would spur modeling studies across carbon nanomaterials as synthesized via CVD or pyrolysis processes, including fullerenes, nanotubes and graphene.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soot is an incidental byproduct of combustion. Combustion is central to most power generation and transportation. Though useful in flames for radiative heat transfer, when emitted from the flame, it is a pollutant and health hazard. This work has shown that soot varies with the combustion – its structure depends upon how much fuel relative to air is present in the combustion system. This is because as the fuel-to-air ratio changes, the combustion chemistry changes. This chemistry is reflected in the soot structure – as observed using electron-based microscopy given that soot particles are sub-micron in size. Moreover the type of fuel also contributes to soot structure. Different fuels have different concentrations of aromatic, naphthenes and paraffins. The combustion chemistry also depends on the relative concentrations of these three components.

 

In these studies we have varied the fuel-to-air ratio to test these concepts, with focus upon those combustion conditions producing soot. Using simple fuels to map the dependence of soot structure using a diffusion flame, observations showed a strong dependence of soot structure upon the fuel-to-air ratio. These results confirmed the postulated role of oxygen upon flame chemistry and resulting impact upon soot structure. We have also compared the soot structure produced by burning real fuels, such as petroleum based and an alternative, renewable jet fuel using a premixed flame. In this latter system the observed soot structure was compared to chemical model calculations of the flame chemistry, representing these different fuels. The chemical species profiles confirmed the postulated dependence of soot structure upon fuel composition – through its impact upon flame chemistry. Better understanding of soot structure can bring insight into how to engineer combustion efficiency and eliminate emitted soot.

 

This project provided the basis and support for a student to graduate with a Ph.D. Technical results of the study are summarized in the Final Report to NSF, were presented at combustion and chemistry conferences and are being documented for publication in archival journals.


Last Modified: 03/12/2015
Modified by: Randy L Vander Wal
